author: sky.cactus
content: <@552133098075193354> I believe you are referring to selfish mining attacks which increase in profitability the larger the ratio of fees to block reward.

author: sky.cactus
content: There is an academic paper about it, and it has been talked about/referenced a lot in the past but I'm not sure if there is a nice "consumer friendly" version anywhere.

author: sky.cactus
content: 1559 solves it by simply reducing transaction fees to near 0 so that ratio remains *very* low.

author: barnabemonnot
content: MEV goes beyond only selfish mining, where i interpret selfish mining as mining on your private chain and releasing strategically to orphan other blocks

author: barnabemonnot
content: time bandit attacks for instance, where a miner does a short reorg to capture a high fee-paying transaction. this is somewhat mitigated by 1559 since basefee is burnt, but you can have high tips when there are bots trying to frontrun in a bidding war

author: barnabemonnot
content: then there is MEV where the miner simply censors such transactions that attempt to arbitrage some situation, and the miner includes its own transaction instead to capture the arbitrage. 1559 doesn't change anything in this case

author: barnabemonnot
content: is the academic paper you mention "on the instability of bitcoin without the block reward"?
